â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : curl: libcurl: ASN.1 date parser overread 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : libcurl's ASN1 parser code has the `GTime2str()`
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   function, used for parsing an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   ASN.1 Generalized Time field. If given an syntactically
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   incorrect field, the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parser might end up using -1 for the length of the *time
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   fraction*, leading to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   a `strlen()` getting performed on a pointer to a heap
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   buffer area that is not
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (purposely) null terminated.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This flaw most likely leads to a crash, but can also lead
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   to heap contents
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   getting returned to the application when
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   [CURLINFO_CERTINFO](https://curl.se/libcurl/c/CURLINFO_CER
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   TINFO.html) is used.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   delivered

â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   users to crash dbus-daemon. If a privileged user with

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : openssl: Unbounded memory growth with session
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   handling in TLSv1.3 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Some non-default TLS server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configurations can cause unbounded
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   memory growth when processing TLSv1.3 sessions
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: An attacker may exploit certain server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configurations to trigger
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   unbounded memory growth that would lead to a Denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Service
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This problem can occur in TLSv1.3 if the non-default
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_OP_NO_TICKET option is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   being used (but not if early_data support is also
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configured and the default
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   anti-replay protection is in use). In this case, under
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   certain conditions, the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   session cache can get into an incorrect state and it will
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   fail to flush properly
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   as it fills. The session cache will continue to grow in an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    unbounded manner. A
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   malicious client could deliberately create the scenario
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   for this failure to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   force a Denial of Service. It may also happen by accident
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   in normal operation.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This issue only affects TLS servers supporting TLSv1.3. It
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    does not affect TLS
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   clients.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this issue. OpenSSL
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   1.0.2 is also not affected by this issue.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : openssl: Excessive time spent checking DSA keys and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Checking excessively long DSA keys or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters may be very
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   slow.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: Applications that use the functions
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_param_check()
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   or EVP_PKEY_public_check() to check a DSA public key or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   DSA parameters may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   experience long delays. Where the key or parameters that
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   are being checked
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   have been obtained from an untrusted source this may lead
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   to a Denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Service.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The functions EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check() perform
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   various checks on DSA parameters. Some of those
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   computations take a long time
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   if the modulus (`p` parameter) is too large.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Trying to use a very large modulus is slow and OpenSSL
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   will not allow using
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   public keys with a modulus which is over 10,000 bits in
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   length for signature
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   verification. However the key and parameter check
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   functions do not limit
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   the modulus size when performing the checks.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   An application that calls EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check()
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   and supplies a key or parameters obtained from an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   untrusted source could be
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   These functions are not called by OpenSSL itself on
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   untrusted DSA keys so
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   only applications that directly call these functions may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be vulnerable.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL pkey and pkeyparam command
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    line applications
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   when using the `-check` option.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are affected by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this issue.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : openssl: SSL_select_next_proto buffer overread 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Calling the OpenSSL API function
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto with an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   empty supported client protocols buffer may cause a crash
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   or memory contents to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be sent to the peer.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: A buffer overread can have a range of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   potential consequences
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   such as unexpected application beahviour or a crash. In
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   particular this issue
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   could result in up to 255 bytes of arbitrary private data
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   from memory being sent
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   to the peer leading to a loss of confidentiality. However,
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    only applications
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   that directly call the SSL_select_next_proto function with
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    a 0 length list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   supported client protocols are affected by this issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This would normally never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be a valid scenario and is typically not under attacker
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   control but may occur by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accident in the case of a configuration or programming
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   error in the calling
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL API function SSL_select_next_proto is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   typically used by TLS
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   applications that support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    Negotiation) or NPN
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (Next Protocol Negotiation). NPN is older, was never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   standardised and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   is deprecated in favour of ALPN. We believe that ALPN is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   widely deployed than NPN. The SSL_select_next_proto
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   function accepts a list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   protocols from the server and a list of protocols from the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    client and returns
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   the first protocol that appears in the server list that
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   also appears in the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client list. In the case of no overlap between the two
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   lists it returns the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   first item in the client list. In either case it will
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   signal whether an overlap
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   between the two lists was found. In the case where
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   called with a zero length client list it fails to notice
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this condition and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   returns the memory immediately following the client list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   pointer (and reports
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   that there was no overlap in the lists).
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This function is typically called from a server side
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application callback for
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   ALPN or a client side application callback for NPN. In the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    case of ALPN the list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   of protocols supplied by the client is guaranteed by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   libssl to never be zero in
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   length. The list of server protocols comes from the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application and should never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   normally be expected to be of zero length. In this case if
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto function has been called as expected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    (with the list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   supplied by the client passed in the client/client_len
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters), then the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application will not be vulnerable to this issue. If the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application has
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally been configured with a zero length server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   list, and has
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally passed that zero length server list in the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client/client_len
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters, and has additionally failed to correctly
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   handle a "no overlap"
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   response (which would normally result in a handshake
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   failure in ALPN) then it
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   will be vulnerable to this problem.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   In the case of NPN, the protocol permits the client to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   opportunistically select
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   a protocol when there is no overlap. OpenSSL returns the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   first client protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   in the no overlap case in support of this. The list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client protocols comes
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   from the application and should never normally be expected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    to be of zero length.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   However if the SSL_select_next_proto function is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally called with a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client_len of 0 then an invalid memory pointer will be
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   returned instead. If the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application uses this output as the opportunistic protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    then the loss of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   confidentiality will occur.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This issue has been assessed as Low severity because
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   applications are most
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   likely to be vulnerable if they are using NPN instead of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   ALPN - but NPN is not
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   widely used. It also requires an application configuration
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    or programming error.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Finally, this issue would not typically be under attacker
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   control making active
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   exploitation unlikely.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.3, 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    by this issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Due to the low severity of this issue we are not issuing
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   new releases of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   OpenSSL at this time. The fix will be included in the next
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    releases when they
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   become available.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : shadow: Improper input validation in shadow-utils
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be able to convince a system administrator to take the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   rogue user account.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : openssl: Unbounded memory growth with session
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   handling in TLSv1.3 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Some non-default TLS server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configurations can cause unbounded
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   memory growth when processing TLSv1.3 sessions
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: An attacker may exploit certain server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configurations to trigger
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   unbounded memory growth that would lead to a Denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Service
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This problem can occur in TLSv1.3 if the non-default
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_OP_NO_TICKET option is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   being used (but not if early_data support is also
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   configured and the default
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   anti-replay protection is in use). In this case, under
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   certain conditions, the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   session cache can get into an incorrect state and it will
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   fail to flush properly
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   as it fills. The session cache will continue to grow in an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    unbounded manner. A
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   malicious client could deliberately create the scenario
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   for this failure to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   force a Denial of Service. It may also happen by accident
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   in normal operation.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This issue only affects TLS servers supporting TLSv1.3. It
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    does not affect TLS
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   clients.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this issue. OpenSSL
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   1.0.2 is also not affected by this issue.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Checking excessively long DSA keys or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters may be very
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   slow.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: Applications that use the functions
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_param_check()
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   or EVP_PKEY_public_check() to check a DSA public key or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   DSA parameters may

â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   are being checked
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   have been obtained from an untrusted source this may lead
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   to a Denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Service.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The functions EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check() perform
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   various checks on DSA parameters. Some of those
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   computations take a long time
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   if the modulus (`p` parameter) is too large.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Trying to use a very large modulus is slow and OpenSSL
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   will not allow using
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   public keys with a modulus which is over 10,000 bits in
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   length for signature
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   verification. However the key and parameter check
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   functions do not limit
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   the modulus size when performing the checks.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   An application that calls EVP_PKEY_param_check() or
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   EVP_PKEY_public_check()
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   and supplies a key or parameters obtained from an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   untrusted source could be
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   These functions are not called by OpenSSL itself on
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   untrusted DSA keys so
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   only applications that directly call these functions may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be vulnerable.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Also vulnerable are the OpenSSL pkey and pkeyparam command
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    line applications
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   when using the `-check` option.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL SSL/TLS implementation is not affected by this
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL 3.0 and 3.1 FIPS providers are affected by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this issue.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : openssl: SSL_select_next_proto buffer overread 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : Issue summary: Calling the OpenSSL API function
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto with an
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   empty supported client protocols buffer may cause a crash
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   or memory contents to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be sent to the peer.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Impact summary: A buffer overread can have a range of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   potential consequences
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   such as unexpected application beahviour or a crash. In
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   particular this issue
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   could result in up to 255 bytes of arbitrary private data
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   from memory being sent
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   to the peer leading to a loss of confidentiality. However,
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    only applications
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   that directly call the SSL_select_next_proto function with
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    a 0 length list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   supported client protocols are affected by this issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This would normally never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be a valid scenario and is typically not under attacker
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   control but may occur by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accident in the case of a configuration or programming
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   error in the calling
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The OpenSSL API function SSL_select_next_proto is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   typically used by TLS
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   applications that support ALPN (Application Layer Protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    Negotiation) or NPN
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (Next Protocol Negotiation). NPN is older, was never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   standardised and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   is deprecated in favour of ALPN. We believe that ALPN is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   widely deployed than NPN. The SSL_select_next_proto
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   function accepts a list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   protocols from the server and a list of protocols from the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    client and returns
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   the first protocol that appears in the server list that
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   also appears in the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client list. In the case of no overlap between the two
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   lists it returns the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   first item in the client list. In either case it will
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   signal whether an overlap
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   between the two lists was found. In the case where
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   called with a zero length client list it fails to notice
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this condition and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   returns the memory immediately following the client list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   pointer (and reports
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   that there was no overlap in the lists).
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This function is typically called from a server side
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application callback for
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   ALPN or a client side application callback for NPN. In the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    case of ALPN the list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   of protocols supplied by the client is guaranteed by
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   libssl to never be zero in
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   length. The list of server protocols comes from the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application and should never
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   normally be expected to be of zero length. In this case if
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   SSL_select_next_proto function has been called as expected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    (with the list
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   supplied by the client passed in the client/client_len
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters), then the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application will not be vulnerable to this issue. If the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application has
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally been configured with a zero length server
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   list, and has
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally passed that zero length server list in the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client/client_len
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   parameters, and has additionally failed to correctly
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   handle a "no overlap"
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   response (which would normally result in a handshake
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   failure in ALPN) then it
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   will be vulnerable to this problem.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   In the case of NPN, the protocol permits the client to
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   opportunistically select
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   a protocol when there is no overlap. OpenSSL returns the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   first client protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   in the no overlap case in support of this. The list of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client protocols comes
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   from the application and should never normally be expected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    to be of zero length.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   However if the SSL_select_next_proto function is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   accidentally called with a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   client_len of 0 then an invalid memory pointer will be
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   returned instead. If the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   application uses this output as the opportunistic protocol
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    then the loss of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   confidentiality will occur.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   This issue has been assessed as Low severity because
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   applications are most
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   likely to be vulnerable if they are using NPN instead of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   ALPN - but NPN is not
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   widely used. It also requires an application configuration
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    or programming error.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Finally, this issue would not typically be under attacker
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   control making active
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   exploitation unlikely.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   The FIPS modules in 3.3, 3.2, 3.1 and 3.0 are not affected
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    by this issue.
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Due to the low severity of this issue we are not issuing
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   new releases of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   OpenSSL at this time. The fix will be included in the next
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    releases when they
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   become available.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Title           : shadow: Improper input validation in shadow-utils
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be able to convince a system administrator to take the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   rogue user account.

â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   package utility chfn 
â”‚                        â”‚       â”œ Description     : In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                    in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   Unicode characters to work around blocking of the :
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   character make it possible to give the impression that a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   be able to convince a system administrator to take the
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a
â”‚                        â”‚       â”‚                   rogue user account.

â”‚                              â”œ Title           : jsoup: The jsoup cleaner may incorrectly sanitize
â”‚                              â”‚                   crafted XSS attempts if SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks is
â”‚                              â”‚                   enabled 
â”‚                              â”œ Description     : jsoup is a Java HTML parser, built for HTML editing,
â”‚                              â”‚                   cleaning, scraping, and cross-site scripting (XSS) safety.
â”‚                              â”‚                   jsoup may incorrectly sanitize HTML including `javascript:`
â”‚                              â”‚                   URL expressions, which could allow XSS attacks when a reader
â”‚                              â”‚                    subsequently clicks that link. If the non-default
â”‚                              â”‚                   `SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks` option is enabled, HTML
â”‚                              â”‚                   including `javascript:` URLs that have been crafted with
â”‚                              â”‚                   control characters will not be sanitized. If the site that
â”‚                              â”‚                   this HTML is published on does not set a Content Security
â”‚                              â”‚                   Policy, an XSS attack is then possible. This issue is
â”‚                              â”‚                   patched in jsoup 1.15.3. Users should upgrade to this
â”‚                              â”‚                   version. Additionally, as the unsanitized input may have
â”‚                              â”‚                   been persisted, old content should be cleaned again using
â”‚                              â”‚                   the updated version. To remediate this issue without
â”‚                              â”‚                   immediately upgrading: - disable
â”‚                              â”‚                   `SafeList.preserveRelativeLinks`, which will rewrite input
â”‚                              â”‚                   URLs as absolute URLs - ensure an appropriate [Content
â”‚                              â”‚                   Security
â”‚                              â”‚                   Policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CS
â”‚                              â”‚                   P) is defined. (This should be used regardless of upgrading,
â”‚                              â”‚                    as a defence-in-depth best practice.)

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting, resetting an
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   in-progress request allows the attacker to create a new
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request while the existing one is still executing. With the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now bound the number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   simultaneously executing handler goroutines to the stream
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   concurrency limit (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arriving when at the limit (which can only happen after the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    client has reset an existing, in-flight request) will be
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   queued until a handler exits. If the request queue grows
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   too large, the server will terminate the connection. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   issue is also fixed in golang.org/x/net/http2 for users
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   manually configuring HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    limit is 250 streams (requests) per HTTP/2 connection.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   This value may be adjusted using the golang.org/x/net/http2
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    package; see the Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the ConfigureServer function.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames on a connection. When a request's
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   headers exceed MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   store the excess headers, but they are still parsed. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   permits an attacker to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data, all associated with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request which is going to be rejected. These headers can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   include Huffman-encoded data which is significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   expensive for the receiver to decode than for an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to send. The fix sets a limit on the amount of excess
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   header frames we will process before closing a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   connection.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting, resetting an
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   in-progress request allows the attacker to create a new
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request while the existing one is still executing. With the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now bound the number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   simultaneously executing handler goroutines to the stream
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   concurrency limit (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arriving when at the limit (which can only happen after the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    client has reset an existing, in-flight request) will be
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   queued until a handler exits. If the request queue grows
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   too large, the server will terminate the connection. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   issue is also fixed in golang.org/x/net/http2 for users
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   manually configuring HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    limit is 250 streams (requests) per HTTP/2 connection.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   This value may be adjusted using the golang.org/x/net/http2
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    package; see the Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the ConfigureServer function.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as sp ... 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as special. On Windows, a path beginning with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ is a Root Local Device path equivalent to a path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   beginning with \\?\. Paths with a \??\ prefix may be used
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to access arbitrary locations on the system. For example,
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the path \??\c:\x is equivalent to the more common path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   c:\x. Before fix, Clean could convert a rooted path such as
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    \a\..\??\b into the root local device path \??\b. Clean
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   will now convert this to .\??\b. Similarly, Join(\, ??, b)
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   could convert a seemingly innocent sequence of path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   elements into the root local device path \??\b. Join will
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   now convert this to \.\??\b. In addition, with fix, IsAbs
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   now correctly reports paths beginning with \??\ as
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   absolute, and VolumeName correctly reports the \??\ prefix
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   as a volume name. UPDATE: Go 1.20.11 and Go 1.21.4
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   inadvertently changed the definition of the volume name in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Windows paths starting with \?, resulting in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   filepath.Clean(\?\c:) returning \?\c: rather than \?\c:\
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   (among other effects). The previous behavior has been
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   restored.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames on a connection. When a request's
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   headers exceed MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   store the excess headers, but they are still parsed. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   permits an attacker to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data, all associated with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request which is going to be rejected. These headers can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   include Huffman-encoded data which is significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   expensive for the receiver to decode than for an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to send. The fix sets a limit on the amount of excess
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   header frames we will process before closing a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   connection.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: insufficient sanitization of Host header 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : The HTTP/1 client does not fully validate the contents
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    of the Host header. A maliciously crafted Host header can

â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   invalid Request.Host or Request.URL.Host value.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: crypto/tls: slow verification of certificate
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   chains containing large RSA keys 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : Extremely large RSA keys in certificate chains can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a client/server to expend significant CPU time
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   verifying signatures. With fix, the size of RSA keys
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   transmitted during handshakes is restricted to <= 8192
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   bits. Based on a survey of publicly trusted RSA keys, there
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    are currently only three certificates in circulation with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   keys larger than this, and all three appear to be test
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   certificates that are not actively deployed. It is possible
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    there are larger keys in use in private PKIs, but we
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   target the web PKI, so causing breakage here in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   interests of increasing the default safety of users of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   crypto/tls seems reasonable.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/internal: Denial of Service (DoS) via
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    Resource Consumption via HTTP requests 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP sender can use chunk extensions to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a receiver reading from a request or response body to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    read many more bytes from the network than are in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   body. A malicious HTTP client can further exploit this to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a server to automatically read a large amount of data
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    (up to about 1GiB) when a handler fails to read the entire
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    body of a request. Chunk extensions are a little-used HTTP
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    feature which permit including additional metadata in a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request or response body sent using the chunked encoding.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   The net/http chunked encoding reader discards this
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   metadata. A sender can exploit this by inserting a large
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   metadata segment with each byte transferred. The chunk
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   reader now produces an error if the ratio of real body to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   encoded bytes grows too small.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : On Windows, The IsLocal function does not correctly
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   detect reserved device names in some cases. Reserved names
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   followed by spaces, such as "COM1 ", and reserved names
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   "COM" and "LPT" followed by superscript 1, 2, or 3, are
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   incorrectly reported as local. With fix, IsLocal now
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   correctly reports these names as non-local.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: memory exhaustion in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : When parsing a multipart form (either explicitly with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm or implicitly with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormValue, Request.PostFormValue, or
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormFile), limits on the total size of the parsed
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   form were not applied to the memory consumed while reading
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   a single form line. This permits a maliciously crafted
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   input containing very long lines to cause allocation of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrarily large amounts of memory, potentially leading to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    memory exhaustion. With fix, the ParseMultipartForm
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   function now correctly limits the maximum size of form
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   lines.

â”‚                               â”œ Title           : net/http: Denial of service due to improper
â”‚                               â”‚                   100-continue handling in net/http 
â”‚                               â”œ Description     : The net/http HTTP/1.1 client mishandled the case where
â”‚                               â”‚                    a server responds to a request with an "Expect:
â”‚                               â”‚                   100-continue" header with a non-informational (200 or
â”‚                               â”‚                   higher) status. This mishandling could leave a client
â”‚                               â”‚                   connection in an invalid state, where the next request sent
â”‚                               â”‚                    on the connection will fail. An attacker sending a request
â”‚                               â”‚                    to a net/http/httputil.ReverseProxy proxy can exploit this
â”‚                               â”‚                    mishandling to cause a denial of service by sending
â”‚                               â”‚                   "Expect: 100-continue" requests which elicit a
â”‚                               â”‚                   non-informational response from the backend. Each such
â”‚                               â”‚                   request leaves the proxy with an invalid connection, and
â”‚                               â”‚                   causes one subsequent request using that connection to
â”‚                               â”‚                   fail.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting, resetting an
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   in-progress request allows the attacker to create a new
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request while the existing one is still executing. With the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now bound the number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   simultaneously executing handler goroutines to the stream
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   concurrency limit (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arriving when at the limit (which can only happen after the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    client has reset an existing, in-flight request) will be
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   queued until a handler exits. If the request queue grows
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   too large, the server will terminate the connection. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   issue is also fixed in golang.org/x/net/http2 for users
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   manually configuring HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    limit is 250 streams (requests) per HTTP/2 connection.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   This value may be adjusted using the golang.org/x/net/http2
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    package; see the Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the ConfigureServer function.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames on a connection. When a request's
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   headers exceed MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   store the excess headers, but they are still parsed. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   permits an attacker to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data, all associated with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request which is going to be rejected. These headers can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   include Huffman-encoded data which is significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   expensive for the receiver to decode than for an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to send. The fix sets a limit on the amount of excess
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   header frames we will process before closing a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   connection.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: rapid stream resets can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    cause excessive work (CVE-2023-44487) 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP/2 client which rapidly creates
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests and immediately resets them can cause excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   server resource consumption. While the total number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requests is bounded by the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   http2.Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting, resetting an
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   in-progress request allows the attacker to create a new
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request while the existing one is still executing. With the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    fix applied, HTTP/2 servers now bound the number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   simultaneously executing handler goroutines to the stream
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   concurrency limit (MaxConcurrentStreams). New requests
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arriving when at the limit (which can only happen after the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    client has reset an existing, in-flight request) will be
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   queued until a handler exits. If the request queue grows
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   too large, the server will terminate the connection. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   issue is also fixed in golang.org/x/net/http2 for users
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   manually configuring HTTP/2. The default stream concurrency
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    limit is 250 streams (requests) per HTTP/2 connection.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   This value may be adjusted using the golang.org/x/net/http2
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    package; see the Server.MaxConcurrentStreams setting and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the ConfigureServer function.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as sp ... 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : The filepath package does not recognize paths with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ prefix as special. On Windows, a path beginning with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   \??\ is a Root Local Device path equivalent to a path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   beginning with \\?\. Paths with a \??\ prefix may be used
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to access arbitrary locations on the system. For example,
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   the path \??\c:\x is equivalent to the more common path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   c:\x. Before fix, Clean could convert a rooted path such as
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    \a\..\??\b into the root local device path \??\b. Clean
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   will now convert this to .\??\b. Similarly, Join(\, ??, b)
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   could convert a seemingly innocent sequence of path
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   elements into the root local device path \??\b. Join will
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   now convert this to \.\??\b. In addition, with fix, IsAbs
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   now correctly reports paths beginning with \??\ as
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   absolute, and VolumeName correctly reports the \??\ prefix
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   as a volume name. UPDATE: Go 1.20.11 and Go 1.21.4
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   inadvertently changed the definition of the volume name in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Windows paths starting with \?, resulting in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   filepath.Clean(\?\c:) returning \?\c: rather than \?\c:\
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   (among other effects). The previous behavior has been
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   restored.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http, x/net/http2: unlimited number of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames causes DoS 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : An attacker may cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data by sending an excessive
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   number of CONTINUATION frames. Maintaining HPACK state
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   requires parsing and processing all HEADERS and
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   CONTINUATION frames on a connection. When a request's
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   headers exceed MaxHeaderBytes, no memory is allocated to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   store the excess headers, but they are still parsed. This
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   permits an attacker to cause an HTTP/2 endpoint to read
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrary amounts of header data, all associated with a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request which is going to be rejected. These headers can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   include Huffman-encoded data which is significantly more
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   expensive for the receiver to decode than for an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   to send. The fix sets a limit on the amount of excess
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   header frames we will process before closing a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   connection.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : The HTTP/1 client does not fully validate the contents
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    of the Host header. A maliciously crafted Host header can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   inject additional headers or entire requests. With fix, the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    HTTP/1 client now refuses to send requests containing an
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   invalid Request.Host or Request.URL.Host value.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: crypto/tls: slow verification of certificate
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   chains containing large RSA keys 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : Extremely large RSA keys in certificate chains can
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a client/server to expend significant CPU time
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   verifying signatures. With fix, the size of RSA keys
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   transmitted during handshakes is restricted to <= 8192
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   bits. Based on a survey of publicly trusted RSA keys, there
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    are currently only three certificates in circulation with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   keys larger than this, and all three appear to be test
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   certificates that are not actively deployed. It is possible
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    there are larger keys in use in private PKIs, but we
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   target the web PKI, so causing breakage here in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   interests of increasing the default safety of users of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   crypto/tls seems reasonable.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/internal: Denial of Service (DoS) via
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    Resource Consumption via HTTP requests 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : A malicious HTTP sender can use chunk extensions to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a receiver reading from a request or response body to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    read many more bytes from the network than are in the
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   body. A malicious HTTP client can further exploit this to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   cause a server to automatically read a large amount of data
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    (up to about 1GiB) when a handler fails to read the entire
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    body of a request. Chunk extensions are a little-used HTTP
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    feature which permit including additional metadata in a
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   request or response body sent using the chunked encoding.
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   The net/http chunked encoding reader discards this
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   metadata. A sender can exploit this by inserting a large
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   metadata segment with each byte transferred. The chunk
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   reader now produces an error if the ratio of real body to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   encoded bytes grows too small.

â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   followed by spaces, such as "COM1 ", and reserved names
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   "COM" and "LPT" followed by superscript 1, 2, or 3, are

â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http/cookiejar: incorrect forwarding of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   sensitive headers and cookies on HTTP redirect 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : When following an HTTP redirect to a domain which is
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   not a subdomain match or exact match of the initial domain,
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    an http.Client does not forward sensitive headers such as
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   "Authorization" or "Cookie". For example, a redirect from
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   foo.com to www.foo.com will forward the Authorization
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   header, but a redirect to bar.com will not. A maliciously
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   crafted HTTP redirect could cause sensitive headers to be
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   unexpectedly forwarded.
