â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Title           : golang: net/http: memory exhaustion in
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm 
â”‚                        â”‚      â”œ Description     : When parsing a multipart form (either explicitly with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.ParseMultipartForm or implicitly with
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormValue, Request.PostFormValue, or
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   Request.FormFile), limits on the total size of the parsed
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   form were not applied to the memory consumed while reading
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   a single form line. This permits a maliciously crafted
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   input containing very long lines to cause allocation of
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   arbitrarily large amounts of memory, potentially leading to
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                    memory exhaustion. With fix, the ParseMultipartForm
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   function now correctly limits the maximum size of form
â”‚                        â”‚      â”‚                   lines.

â”‚                               â”œ Title           : net/http: Denial of service due to improper
â”‚                               â”‚                   100-continue handling in net/http 
â”‚                               â”œ Description     : The net/http HTTP/1.1 client mishandled the case where
â”‚                               â”‚                    a server responds to a request with an "Expect:
â”‚                               â”‚                   100-continue" header with a non-informational (200 or
â”‚                               â”‚                   higher) status. This mishandling could leave a client
â”‚                               â”‚                   connection in an invalid state, where the next request sent
â”‚                               â”‚                    on the connection will fail. An attacker sending a request
â”‚                               â”‚                    to a net/http/httputil.ReverseProxy proxy can exploit this
â”‚                               â”‚                    mishandling to cause a denial of service by sending
â”‚                               â”‚                   "Expect: 100-continue" requests which elicit a
â”‚                               â”‚                   non-informational response from the backend. Each such
â”‚                               â”‚                   request leaves the proxy with an invalid connection, and
â”‚                               â”‚                   causes one subsequent request using that connection to
â”‚                               â”‚                   fail.

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : moby: Authz zero length regression 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Moby is an open-source project created by Docker for
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   software containerization. A security vulnerability has been
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    detected in certain versions of Docker Engine, which could
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   allow an attacker to bypass authorization plugins (AuthZ)
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   under specific circumstances. The base likelihood of this
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   being exploited is low.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Using a specially-crafted API request, an Engine API client
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   could make the daemon forward the request or response to an
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   authorization plugin without the body. In certain
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   circumstances, the authorization plugin may allow a request
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   which it would have otherwise denied if the body had been
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   forwarded to it.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   A security issue was discovered In 2018, where an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   could bypass AuthZ plugins using a specially crafted API
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   request. This could lead to unauthorized actions, including
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   privilege escalation. Although this issue was fixed in
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker Engine v18.09.1 in January 2019, the fix was not
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   carried forward to later major versions, resulting in a
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   regression. Anyone who depends on authorization plugins that
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    introspect the request and/or response body to make access
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   control decisions is potentially impacted.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker EE v19.03.x and all versions of Mirantis Container
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Runtime are not vulnerable.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   docker-ce v27.1.1 containes patches to fix the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   vulnerability. Patches have also been merged into the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   master, 19.03, 20.0, 23.0, 24.0, 25.0, 26.0, and 26.1
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   release branches. If one is unable to upgrade immediately,
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   avoid using AuthZ plugins and/or restrict access to the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker API to trusted parties, following the principle of
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   least privilege.

â”‚                              â”œ Title           : net/http: Denial of service due to improper
â”‚                              â”‚                   100-continue handling in net/http 
â”‚                              â”œ Description     : The net/http HTTP/1.1 client mishandled the case where
â”‚                              â”‚                   a server responds to a request with an "Expect:
â”‚                              â”‚                   100-continue" header with a non-informational (200 or
â”‚                              â”‚                   higher) status. This mishandling could leave a client
â”‚                              â”‚                   connection in an invalid state, where the next request sent
â”‚                              â”‚                   on the connection will fail. An attacker sending a request
â”‚                              â”‚                   to a net/http/httputil.ReverseProxy proxy can exploit this
â”‚                              â”‚                   mishandling to cause a denial of service by sending "Expect:
â”‚                              â”‚                    100-continue" requests which elicit a non-informational
â”‚                              â”‚                   response from the backend. Each such request leaves the
â”‚                              â”‚                   proxy with an invalid connection, and causes one subsequent
â”‚                              â”‚                   request using that connection to fail.

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : moby: Authz zero length regression 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : Moby is an open-source project created by Docker for
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   software containerization. A security vulnerability has been
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    detected in certain versions of Docker Engine, which could
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   allow an attacker to bypass authorization plugins (AuthZ)
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   under specific circumstances. The base likelihood of this
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   being exploited is low.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Using a specially-crafted API request, an Engine API client
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   could make the daemon forward the request or response to an
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   authorization plugin without the body. In certain
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   circumstances, the authorization plugin may allow a request
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   which it would have otherwise denied if the body had been
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   forwarded to it.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   A security issue was discovered In 2018, where an attacker
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   could bypass AuthZ plugins using a specially crafted API
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   request. This could lead to unauthorized actions, including
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   privilege escalation. Although this issue was fixed in
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker Engine v18.09.1 in January 2019, the fix was not
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   carried forward to later major versions, resulting in a
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   regression. Anyone who depends on authorization plugins that
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                    introspect the request and/or response body to make access
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   control decisions is potentially impacted.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker EE v19.03.x and all versions of Mirantis Container
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Runtime are not vulnerable.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   docker-ce v27.1.1 containes patches to fix the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   vulnerability. Patches have also been merged into the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   master, 19.03, 20.0, 23.0, 24.0, 25.0, 26.0, and 26.1
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   release branches. If one is unable to upgrade immediately,
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   avoid using AuthZ plugins and/or restrict access to the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   Docker API to trusted parties, following the principle of
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   least privilege.

â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Title           : Private tokens could appear in logs if context
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   containing gRPC metadata is logged in
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   github.com/grpc/grpc-go 
â”‚                        â”‚     â”œ Description     : ### Impact
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   This issue represents a potential PII concern.  If
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   applications were printing or logging a context containing
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   gRPC metadata, the affected versions will contain all the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   metadata, which may include private information.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   ### Patches
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   The issue first appeared in 1.64.0 and is patched in 1.64.1
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   and 1.65.0
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   ### Workarounds
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   If using an affected version and upgrading is not possible,
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   ensuring you do not log or print contexts will avoid the
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚                   problem.
â”‚                        â”‚     â”‚

â”‚                              â”‚                   response from the backend. Each such request leaves the
â”‚                              â”‚                   proxy with an invalid connection, and causes one subsequent
â”‚                              â”‚                   request using that connection to fail.
